NEW YORK STATE EDUCATIONAL RADIO AND TELEVISION ASSOCIATION
Report of the Research Committee
April 5, 1963
The committee reviewed the preliminary reports of television research
conducted of broadcast television in New York City by the Bureau of Applied
Social Research under contract to the State Education Department and in
Buffalo by the staff ef WNED-TV in cooperation with the area educational
television coordinators. The audiences for each open circuit installation
were found to be increasing; the programs were said to be improving in
quality and school administrators were largely in favor of the success of
the programs.
A shortage of television sets still remains an important obstacle to
greater television utilization. School administrators appeared to be willing
to adjust school bell schedules to accommodate good television programs.
Driver education programs in both cities did not obtain expected viewers.
An increase in recording of better prepared programs was recommended.
The committee will attempt to have reports of those research studies
and ones conducted at Syracuse and Brockport reported at the November
Research and Communications Convocation being organized by the State
Education Department in cooperation with State research, audio-visual, radio
and television organizations.
Larry Myers reported on a study he has underway to determine desirable
traits to be found in television teachers. Mel Smagorinski reported on his
doctoral dissertation which deals with the effectiveness of talkback in
television instruction.
